misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Implemented distance calculator instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The program solves a completely different problem (distance between two points) instead of reading a grade 0–100, using conditional ranges, and printing a letter grade. None of the rubric requirements (single numeric grade input, grade ranges A–F, conditional logic, or letter output) are present.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can submit this distance-between-two-points program for the grade-calculator question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program must read a single numeric grade (0–100), use if/else conditions to check which range it falls into (A: 90–100, B: 80–89, etc.), and then print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade
Program computes a square root distance formula instead of applying grade ranges
No if/else or conditional logic for grade intervals
Output describes distance between two points, not a letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different assignment questions or reusing code from another problem without adapting it to the required grade-calculator specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Rewrite main to read exactly one numeric grade (0–100) from the user, then use an if/else-if chain to check the grade against the specified ranges (A, B, C, D, F) and print the correct letter grade.
related_concepts: Basic input and output with Scanner and System.out
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (prompts, variables, formula, and output) corresponds to a distance-calculation problem rather than a grade-calculator; there is no grading logic at all.

evidence.note: Code reads four coordinate values, computes a distance with Math.sqrt, and prints a distance message instead of handling a single numeric grade and mapping it to a letter.

misconceptions.name: Complete disregard of problem requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the distance between two 2D points, which is a solution to an entirely different problem, likely from a previous or unrelated assignment. The requirements of the 'Grade Calculator' problem were completely ignored.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that the task was to write a program to calculate the distance between two points, or they submitted the incorrect file for this question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task requires a program that reads a single numeric grade (0-100) and uses conditional logic (if/else if/else) to determine and print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: Code reads four double values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one integer grade.
Code calculates Euclidean distance instead of determining a letter grade.
Output is 'The distance of the two points is...' instead of 'Letter grade:'
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding the assignment requirements or submitting the wrong code file.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the prompt for Q3. You need to read a single integer/double for the grade and then implement the grading logic using if-else statements.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The provided code implements a Euclidean distance calculation, which is completely irrelevant to the requested grade calculator. This is a fundamental error in meeting the problem requirements.

evidence.note: The entire logic implements a distance calculation, ignoring the grade calculator problem entirely.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect number and type of inputs
misconceptions.description: The student's code reads four double values (x1, y1, x2, y2) when the required task was to read a single numeric grade (typically an integer or double).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the program requires four separate coordinate inputs.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task only requires reading one numerical input representing the grade.
symptoms: Multiple calls to input.nextDouble() for unrelated variables.
Prompts ask for coordinate pairs instead of a grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: The code corresponds to a different programming problem (distance formula).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: The Grade Calculator only needs one input from the user: the numerical grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The prompts and input mechanisms clearly indicate a different problem setup involving coordinate pairs, not a single grade input.

evidence.note: Reads four double inputs for coordinates, not a single grade.

misconceptions.name: Completely Wrong Problem Implementation
misconceptions.description: The student has implemented a solution for a different problem (distance between two points) instead of the grade calculator problem specified in Q3.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a distance calculation problem, not a grade calculator problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Q3 requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Code prompts for 'x1 and y1' and 'x2 and y2' instead of a grade
Code calculates Euclidean distance instead of mapping grades to letters
No conditional logic for grade ranges present
Output shows distance calculation, not letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted code for the wrong problem entirely, possibly copy-pasting from a different assignment or question.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start fresh with the correct problem: Read one integer grade, use if-else statements to check grade ranges (90-100 for A, 80-89 for B, etc.), and output the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the code solves a completely different problem (distance calculation) with no relation to grade mapping.

evidence.note: The entire program solves a distance calculation problem, not a grade calculator. It reads coordinates and computes Euclidean distance.
No grade input, no conditional logic for grade ranges, no letter grade output. This is completely wrong for the grade calculator problem.

misconceptions.name: Implemented distance calculator instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points rather than a program to read a numeric grade and output a corresponding letter grade using conditional ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can solve this problem by reading two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and printing the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100, then use conditional checks on that single value to determine and print the correct letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) according to the specified ranges.
symptoms: Program prompts for two coordinate pairs instead of a single grade value.
Variables x1, y1, x2, y2 and a distance formula are used instead of a single grade variable.
No conditional statements (if/else) for grade ranges appear in the code.
Output reports the distance between two points, not a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have implemented a solution for a different problem (distance between two points), indicating a mismatch between the problem specification and the implemented algorithm.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and identify the required input (a single numeric grade) and output (a letter grade). Replace the coordinate inputs and distance calculation with reading one grade value and a series of if/else-if/else statements that map the numeric grade to the correct letter grade range.
related_concepts: Program design based on rubric criteria
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the code (inputs, calculations, and output message) corresponds to a distance-formula problem and none of it relates to grades or letter outputs.

evidence.note: This code clearly reads coordinates and computes a geometric distance, with no variables or logic related to grades or letter grade ranges.

misconceptions.name: Solved the wrong problem (Distance Calculation)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for calculating the distance between two points (a common introductory programming problem) instead of the required Grade Calculator problem. No grade input is read, and no grading logic is implemented.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student confused the current assignment (Q3 Grade Calculator) with a previous or different assignment (Distance Formula).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must prompt for and read a single numeric grade (0-100) and then use conditional statements to determine the letter grade.
symptoms: Code prompts for 'x1 and y1' and 'x2 and y2'
Variables x1, y1, x2, y2, and distance are used, not 'grade'
Final output is 'The distance of the two points is...' instead of 'Letter grade:'
Crucial logic (if/else structure for grading) is completely missing
misconceptions.root_cause: Misplaced code or severe misunderstanding of the assignment requirements/context.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the assignment prompt carefully. Delete the distance calculation logic and replace it with code that reads a single 'grade' variable and uses 'if/else if/else' statements to check the grading ranges (90+, 80-89, etc.).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student code implements the Euclidean distance formula exactly, which is completely irrelevant to the grade calculator problem described.

evidence.note: The entire program is dedicated to calculating the distance between two points, not calculating a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Wrong problem solved
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a solution for a distance calculation problem instead of the grade calculator problem specified in Q3.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have either worked on the wrong problem or submitted the incorrect file.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires a grade calculator that reads a numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A-F) based on specified ranges.
symptoms: Code reads x1, y1, x2, y2 coordinates instead of a grade
Code calculates distance using Euclidean formula instead of checking grade ranges
Output shows distance result instead of letter grade
No conditional logic for grade thresholds present
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of the problem requirements or submission of incorrect source file
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the problem statement carefully and ensure you are solving the correct assignment. Write code that reads a single numeric grade, uses if-else statements to check which range it falls into, and outputs the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Near 100% confidence—the code solves a completely different problem. There is no evidence of attempting to implement any part of the grade calculator requirements.

evidence.note: Code requests coordinate inputs instead of a grade value

evidence.snippet:
double distance=Math.sqrt((x2-x1)*(x2-x1)+(y2-y1)*(y2-y1));
System.out.println("The distance of the two points is "+distance);
evidence.note: Code calculates and outputs Euclidean distance rather than letter grade
